title: Will Japan, the People's Republic of China, and South Korea sign a trilateral free trade agreement before 1 January 2022?
preds: They are trying to agree if chicken is turkey and turkey if goose!
Absolutely not. I believe that it will take quite a bit of time to get them to all agree, if it’s even possible.
Not a chance that China & Japan will cooperate based on previous relationships
It is highly unlikely this could be accomplished in such a short period, given the complexity of negotiations
Too late. But with Japan and South Korea on the fence there are lots of challenges to overcome before it happens.
Negotiation didn't start yet. If even it starts tomorrow, likely won't finish it before 1 Jan 2022. Moreover, it is unlikely due to politics.

With no summit, South Korean president to skip Olympics - East Oregonian
https://www.eastoregonian.com/news/nation_world/with-no-summit-south-korean-president-to-skip-olympics/article_77148da5-528b-5891-969b-13f9cbbd7f5e.html
Mon, 19 Jul 2021 11:23:08 GMT
> Relations between Seoul and Tokyo have been strained since South Korea’s Supreme Court in 2018 ordered some Japanese companies to compensate Korean forced laborers for their ordeals during Japan’s 1910-1945 colonial rule of the Korean Peninsula. The rulings led to further tensions over trade when Japan imposed export controls on chemicals vital to South Korea’s semiconductor industry in 2019.
> Seoul accused Tokyo of weaponizing trade and threatened to terminate a military intelligence-sharing agreement with Tokyo that was a major symbol of their trilateral security cooperation with Washington. South Korea eventually backed off and continued the deal after being pressured by the Trump administration, which until then seemed content to let its allies escalate their feud in public.
> “The Moon administration has not made enough domestic progress in addressing legal and historical challenges to diplomacy. Meanwhile, the Suga government has mismanaged the situation by insufficiently prioritizing Korea to the point of discourtesy,” Easley said.
> “Members of the Biden administration are no doubt disappointed while leaders in North Korea and China delight in the disunity of U.S. allies.” 
> Also on Saturday, South Korea’s Olympic Committee removed banners at the Olympic athletes’ village in Tokyo that referred to a 16th-century Korean naval admiral who fought off an invading Japanese fleet after the International Olympic Committee ruled they were provocative.

Likely yes. Partially because for example, Japans travel restirictions currently bans all travel...except from China and South  Korea. These countries also can fuse very good in terms of trade & industry due to similar cultural values. Japan want to wriggle itself from US yoke, China wants to project itself as regional dominant, and if these 2 agree on something - Korea will follow suit.
No interest from at least one of the parties.  Something could change, but highly unlikely.

Regional COVID passport in Asia post G7. Maybe pre G7 as possible COA if other COVID negations fail. Mainly because of geography. How would this impact status of forces agreement for United States? Is Hong Kong a COVID Petrie dish? Hong Kong fog season is upon us.

It is hard to see the logic of such a trilateral agreement when the RCEP has just been signed and it includes all 3 countries mentioned. May a few years later it might happen if there are some issues with the RCEP.
Will Russia stop playing dodge ball?

It seems unlikely that a trilateral free agreement will be signed within the next 11 months given the lack of ongoing negotiations. Additionally, South Korea and Japan will likely want to focus on engaging with the United States under the new administration rather than moving closer to China. China's persistent human rights abuses and its aggressive foreign policy also decrease the likelihood of a trade agreement (see the debate currently occurring within the EU about the Comprehensive Agreement on Investment). Lastly, Japanese firms are seeking to move away from China indicating that the necessity of a trade agreement may begin to decrease as some countries begin to reduce their reliance on the Chinese economy. (https://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2021/01/26/commentary/world-commentary/api-china-trade/)
Down from 16% [1] due to passage of time. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1202538
Japan is having issues with both China and S. Korea when it comes to territorial dispute. It will prevent them from reaching the agreement this year.

The best reference I can find for the average length of regional trade agreement negotiations is 28 months (https://faculty.haas.berkeley.edu/arose/MR2Vox.pdf). This trilateral negotiation already exceeds that by a lot (RCEP was eight years). This fact, plus the claims by Xi that he will accelerate the negotiation now that the RCEP has been concluded, and similar claims from Japan and ROK, suggest an increasing probability of conclusion. The window is almost a full year from now. I think China could put some real momentum behind this agreement if they suspect that it can influence US-China trade with the new administration. I'm aiming a little higher than the crowd forecast, for those reasons: 20%.

RCEP did most of the work and Japan
Will want US in TPP as a higher priority
16 plus rounds of negotiation demonstrate the desire to see this deal thru

It may be contemplated but South Korea and Japan need to reconcile their own approach with the US position in Asia Pacific.  Getting it agreed is one thing, getting it signed another.

Lots of variables around Biden's approach to Asia, whether CP-TPP becomes the main avenue for trade partnerships rather than bi/tri-laterals, any renewals in tensions because of N Korea's actions in coming months etc. Likely to see plenty of discussion, but movement will probably be slow.
The end of the Trump era will increase US involvement in multi lateral deals, reducing the utility of this deal.
It seems highly unlikely that Japan and ROK would do that to Biden in his first year when they rely on the US as their security guarantor.
Little incentive for all parties to sign if this requires compromises on other issues, namely demilitarization of South China Sea.
There is insufficient value to all parties to reach an agreement.
South Korea and Japan are both astute when it comes to China.

1. China military adventures in the South China sea.
2. Disputed islands with Japan.
3. Changes to the relationship with the US as the Biden administration has signaled a multi lateral approach to foreign policy.
4. Issues related to SOE's and their relationship with the Communist Party.
5. Intellectual property trade off with  market access.
6. China has to develop a consumer driven society to maintain its jobs and the income of the worker. The Chinese Communist Party  has to worry about social unrest. The genie of the consumer and increasing standard of living has been unleashed in China. Will they allow other countries to challenge their labor markets?
South China Sea must be demilitarized before any agreement is signed
US will lean on its allies to delay.
Paying deference to the aggregate. Interesting to see how it has fallen so fast.
South Korea will want to see how China and the west re-engage and will not want to sign on to anything that is contrary to what will come, likely later that this date.
I'm going to assume that Japan and South Korea will be a part of the alliance to contain China, and will not sign a trilateral trade deal.
I can't imagine it, but maybe there's a small chance...

There will be general elections in Japan in October 2021, which will make it difficult for the Japanese government to get to a settlement with Korea on the wartime labour compensation issue, and which will also force the Government to take a strong political stance vis-à-vis China's maritime assertiveness.  Furthermore, since the RCEP has been signed in November 2020, the pressure to agree on a tri-lateral trade agreement is not very strong, and discussions to reach such an agreement will be technically challenging.
Korea and Japan will likely waiting until after President Joe Biden determines whether or not the TPP will be revisited.
@pietrokc made some excellent points, but I'm slightly more optimistic of a deal.

Crowd currently at 30% struck me as too high before I did any research. Free trade agreements are extremely complex; about as complex as the developed economies of all 3 countries. Further, agreement between 3 parties is harder to arrive at, than agreement between 2 parties. My mental model is that it is A LOT harder. On the other hand, the new RCEP was signed among 15 countries in ~9y (~7.5y after 1st round of negotiations) [1]; and this China-Japan-South Korea (CJK) agreement has been in the works for ~9 years (1st round of negotiations ~7.5y ago) [2]. Granted, the 15 parties of RCEP were 10 countries that were already in a FTA (ASEAN), plus 5 of their major trading partners, which made it easier. Then again, CJK are now in a FTA of their own, which by this reasoning would make CJK easier! So it's not quite as easy as I thought, to say 30% is too high. BASE RATES
We want to know how many multilateral FTAs are signed per year, more specifically in Asia. I decided to count since 1980 as things longer ago seemed less comparable. (Less communication technology, less globalization etc.) I found 24 FTAs signed since 1980, for a rate of ~0.585/year globally. Now, we are asking about a very specific FTA so the rate for it must be lower. Let's say there are 5 big regions of the world that might do a multilateral FTA, so specifically in Asia we would expect ~0.585/5 = 0.117/year. To get somewhat independent confirmation I counted the FTAs involving at least one East Asian country, and I found 5, for a rate of ~0.122/year. Pretty close to the 0.117 number! It seems like a good base rate --- 12%. Again, this is somewhat of an overestimate as it counts general FTAs in East Asia, not this specific one. INSIDE VIEW
As mentioned, CJK has been in the works for ~9y, and seriously for ~7.5y. They've had 2 meetings per year since 2016 (~3/year until 2015) [1]. It's hard to gauge progress from the minutes, but roughly speaking things were pretty vague until mid-2018. For instance, in the March 2018 meeting the members discussed "areas such as Trade in Goods, Trade in Services, Investment, amongst others" [4]. That's... all of the economy? Literally every meeting before Dec 2018 is described like that. On the Dec 2018 meeting, "the three countries agreed with the acceleration of negotiations on a FTA". But then there were only two meetings after that (Apr 2019, Nov 2019), both described thus: "the three countries had concrete discussions on market access and rules (such as electronic commerce and intellectual property). The three countries also affirmed to continue negotiations toward the conclusion of comprehensive, high-level and mutually beneficial agreement, with regard to the progress of RCEP." There were no meetings in 2020. This could be because they had to finish RCEP? The coronavirus? In any case, after 1 year they were still discussing the same thing ("electronic commerce and intellectual property"). If there are just 1-2 more things of similar complexity to discuss, which almost certainly there are, discussions will easily go on another year. As they get close to a deal, I expect the frequency of meetings to increase, but this has not happened yet. So, based only on the inside view, I'd give this FTA a 20% chance of being concluded in 2021. And this is mostly coming from how little I know about trade negotiations, rather than really thinking there's a nontrivial chance. SYNTHESIS
So if I average my inside and outside views, I get 16%. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Comprehensive_Economic_Partnership
[2] https://www.mofa.go.jp/ecm/ep/page23e_000337.html
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_multilateral_free-trade_agreements
[4] https://www.mofa.go.jp/press/release/press4e_001968.html

Reasoning against...
China is severely disliked by Japan and South Korea. Neither country is keen to see it gain further power and influence, especially with the sudden increase in China's naval power and assertion over the local sea territories (9-dash line claims, etc). China also fails to provide transparency and honesty in its numbers regardless of topic. Increased pressure from the United States of America and other countries has also forced much of China's manufacturing into neighboring countries, particularly Vietnam. Increased class standing within China now means much of the populace has the resources (and time) to truly demand more rights from the Communist Party. Good YouTube sources include "China Uncensored", "America Uncovered", and "ADVChina" (vloggers -- takes time to get specifics needed).  To Be Determined...
Joe Biden. Historically, very pro-trade with China, as well as the majority of his now selected cabinet advisors. However, action against China under Trump has been overwhelmingly supported by both parties and houses within Congress. Even Obama (Biden VP) stopped labelling China as a "partner" and instead referred to the PRC as a "competitor." Which begs the question: What is Joe Biden's strategy towards China? Certainly less hostile than Mr. Trump, but the last four years have shown there is no reset on this relationship to pre-2016.  Unknowns...
How quickly India will actually move in on the smartphone/electronics market from China. At the rate India is moving, it is likely to be a major check on China in the coming decades, but still has some major internal work to do before it is on equal footing. Reasoning for...
China is hurting more from the trade war than it pretends. Much of its prosperity is dependent on keeping good standing with potential trade partners, meaning Japan and South Korea may be able to use economic agreement to curb otherwise hostile behavior. While much manufacturing has moved away, China has managed to start a somewhat internally sustained economy. It has also made strides in its Belt-and-Road initiative, providing a lot of leverage to work with across the entire planet. China is also good at playing with soft power -- something the USA is experiencing the hard way and South Korea is seemingly affected by at its upper levels of government.

Based on the article recommended by @DelapsusAngelus I must reassess my forecast.
The COVID-19 situation will have prevented any in-person meeting in 2020.
There have been at least annual meetings since 2017, two meetings each in 2017 and 2018.
The arrival of possibility for immunization through vaccination (politicians, negotiators, staff, meeting location,...) will further facilitate meetings in 2021 from approx. March, which renders it likely there will be two meetings in 2021, one in each half of the year. There is also an option major talks and/or announcements coincide with the 2020 Tokyo Olympic Games in 2021 - if necessary. Since the trade talks have a long history, and the final agreement will likely have the shape of a "RCEP+" deal, there may not be as many topics open to negotiate. The RCEP deal has already been signed and will deliver a solid foundation of the additional negotiations on selected higher standards. The RCEP signature took place even under pandemic conditions, which underscores the value and the importance to all parties involved. As trade liberalization and the positive effects on trade volume will be viewed as a form of economic pandemic relief, especially with regards to Japan, there will be a large incentive to speed up negotiations to achieve the final agreement in a fast sequence to the RCEP (signature: 11/15 November 2020). The question whether India's final abandon of the RCEP in 2019 will have an influence on the three countries' bilateral respective trade relations with India and thus on the likelihood that a RCEP+/Trilateral agreement will achieve signature stage in the next months, must be further investigated. In addition, if a 9th "China–Japan–South Korea trilateral summit" will be scheduled (current status: "TBD"), this can be a strong indication of progress in negotiations.
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/China%E2%80%93Japan%E2%80%93South_Korea_trilateral_summit
Another occasion to be watched may be the World Economic Forum (WEF) annual meeting, which is about to take place in May 2021 in Singapur as an exception.
https://www.weforum.org/events/the-davos-agenda-2021/about
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Economic_Forum#Annual_meeting_in_Davos There could be some headwinds from the fact that China is neither a member of the Major non-NATO ally (MNNA) club nor of the OECD, and Japan may have its reservations towards the Belt-and-Road Initiative (BRI), which China enforces but Japan lacks a membership, other than South Korea.
However, all three nations should have a common fundamental understanding of trade, as all three of them are members of the G20.
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/China%E2%80%93Japan%E2%80%93South_Korea_trilateral_summit#Organization_and_groups In the light of all this, I expect a signature rather sooner than later, if at all in 2021.
I raise my forecast significantly.

It's difficult to say really. With the signing of RCEP, India walking away from it, a new US president who may (and should in my opinion) re-join the CPTPP...this is actually a far more complex question than it first appears on the surface. I'm in a trade class taught by the guy who says "The RCEP will connect about 30 percent of the world's people and output and, in the right political context, will generate significant gains" (Plummer) and the class has had some interesting conversations revolving around just such a possibility. I personally think a trilateral agreement is more likely than say, the US joining RCEP, but there is still a political dimension to the whole mess. Also, I actually just re-read the question and this is a whole year out...almost too much obscuring mists of time to really see clearly. Crystal ball prediction is 33% chance yes but there are some difficult hurdles to overcome.

If JB maintains DT's trade war with China, then I'll be raising my forecast. Wikipedia was useful: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/China%E2%80%93Japan%E2%80%93South_Korea_Free_Trade_Agreement Edit: on reflection I think I've gone too far under with the crowd, yet the more I think on it, the more I think this happens, too much work has been achieved. Still interested on US/China trade dispute for early 2021.
They haven’t been talking for a decade yet...why the rush?!
